column2: Shall we see you tomorrow to dinner? said Mrs. Dashwood, when he was leaving them.
column3: Shall we see you tomorrow to dinner? said mrs Dashwood, when he was leaving them.

column2: I do not ask you to come in the morning, for we must walk to the park, to call on Lady Middleton.
column3: I do not ask you to come in the morning, for we must walk to the park, to call on Lady Middleton.

column2: He engaged to be with them by four o'clock.
column3: He engaged to be with them by four o'clock.

column2: CHAPTER 15
column3: CHAPTER fifteen

column2: Mrs. Dashwood's visit to Lady Middleton took place the next day, and two of her daughters went with her; but Marianne excused herself from being of the party, under some trifling pretext of employment; and her mother, who concluded that a promise had been made by Willoughby the night before of calling on her while they were absent, was perfectly satisfied with her remaining at home.
column3: mrs Dashwood's visit to Lady Middleton took place the next day, and two of her daughters went with her; but Marianne excused herself from being of the party, under some trifling pretext of employment; and her mother, who concluded that a promise had been made by Willoughby the night before of calling on her while they were absent, was perfectly satisfied with her remaining at home.

column2: On their return from the park they found Willoughby's curricle and servant in waiting at the cottage, and Mrs. Dashwood was convinced that her conjecture had been just.
column3: On their return from the park they found Willoughby's curricle and servant in waiting at the cottage, and mrs Dashwood was convinced that her conjecture had been just.

column2: So far it was all as she had foreseen; but on entering the house she beheld what no foresight had taught her to expect.
column3: So far it was all as she had foreseen; but on entering the house she beheld what no foresight had taught her to expect.

column2: They were no sooner in the passage than Marianne came hastily out of the parlour apparently in violent affliction, with her handkerchief at her eyes; and without noticing them ran up stairs. Surprised and alarmed they proceeded directly into the room she had just quitted, where they found only Willoughby, who was leaning against the mantel-piece with his back towards them.
column3: They were no sooner in the passage than Marianne came hastily out of the parlour apparently in violent affliction, with her handkerchief at her eyes; and without noticing them ran up stairs. Surprised and alarmed they proceeded directly into the room she had just quitted, where they found only Willoughby, who was leaning against the mantel piece with his back towards them.

column2: He turned round on their coming in, and his countenance shewed that he strongly partook of the emotion which over-powered Marianne.
column3: He turned round on their coming in, and his countenance shewed that he strongly partook of the emotion which over powered Marianne.

column2: Is anything the matter with her? cried Mrs. Dashwood as she entered--"is she ill?"
column3: Is anything the matter with her? cried mrs Dashwood as she entered-"is she ill?"

column2: I hope not, he replied, trying to look cheerful; and with a forced smile presently added, "It is I who may rather expect to be ill--for I am now suffering under a very heavy disappointment!"
column3: I hope not, he replied, trying to look cheerful; and with a forced smile presently added, "It is I who may rather expect to be ill-for I am now suffering under a very heavy disappointment!"

column2: Disappointment?
column3: Disappointment?

column2: Yes, for I am unable to keep my engagement with you.	Yes, for I am unable to keep my engagement with you.
column3: true

column2: Mrs. Smith has this morning exercised the privilege of riches upon a poor dependent cousin, by sending me on business to London.
column3: mrs Smith has this morning exercised the privilege of riches upon a poor dependent cousin, by sending me on business to London.

column2: I have just received my dispatches, and taken my farewell of Allenham; and by way of exhilaration I am now come to take my farewell of you."
column3: I have just received my dispatches, and taken my farewell of Allenham; and by way of exhilaration I am now come to take my farewell of you."

column2: To London!--and are you going this morning?
column3: To London!--and are you going this morning?

column2: Almost this moment.
column3: Almost this moment.

column2: This is very unfortunate.	This is very unfortunate.
column3: true

column2: But Mrs. Smith must be obliged;--and her business will not detain you from us long I hope."
column3: But mrs Smith must be obliged;--and her business will not detain you from us long I hope."

column2: He coloured as he replied, "You are very kind, but I have no idea of returning into Devonshire immediately.
column3: He coloured as he replied, "You are very kind, but I have no idea of returning into Devonshire immediately.

column2: My visits to Mrs. Smith are never repeated within the twelvemonth."
column3: My visits to mrs Smith are never repeated within the twelvemonth."

column2: And is Mrs. Smith your only friend?	And is mrs Smith your only friend?
column3: true

column2: Is Allenham the only house in the neighbourhood to which you will be welcome?
column3: Is Allenham the only house in the neighbourhood to which you will be welcome?

column2: For shame, Willoughby, can you wait for an invitation here?"
column3: For shame, Willoughby, can you wait for an invitation here?"

column2: His colour increased; and with his eyes fixed on the ground he only replied, "You are too good."
column3: His colour increased; and with his eyes fixed on the ground he only replied, "You are too good."

column2: Mrs. Dashwood looked at Elinor with surprise.
column3: mrs Dashwood looked at Elinor with surprise.

column2: Elinor felt equal amazement.
column3: Elinor felt equal amazement.

column2: For a few moments every one was silent.
column3: For a few moments every one was silent.

column2: Mrs. Dashwood first spoke.
column3: mrs Dashwood first spoke.

column2: I have only to add, my dear Willoughby, that at Barton cottage you will always be welcome; for I will not press you to return here immediately, because you only can judge how far THAT might be pleasing to Mrs. Smith; and on this head I shall be no more disposed to question your judgment than to doubt your inclination.
column3: I have only to add, my dear Willoughby, that at Barton cottage you will always be welcome; for I will not press you to return here immediately, because you only can judge how far THAT might be pleasing to mrs Smith; and on this head I shall be no more disposed to question your judgment than to doubt your inclination.

column2: My engagements at present, replied Willoughby, confusedly, "are of such a nature--that--I dare not flatter myself"--
column3: My engagements at present, replied Willoughby, confusedly, "are of such a nature-that-I dare not flatter myself"--

column2: He stopt.
column3: He stopt.

column2: Mrs. Dashwood was too much astonished to speak, and another pause succeeded.
column3: mrs Dashwood was too much astonished to speak, and another pause succeeded.

column2: This was broken by Willoughby, who said with a faint smile, "It is folly to linger in this manner.
column3: This was broken by Willoughby, who said with a faint smile, "It is folly to linger in this manner.

column2: I will not torment myself any longer by remaining among friends whose society it is impossible for me now to enjoy."
column3: I will not torment myself any longer by remaining among friends whose society it is impossible for me now to enjoy."

column2: He then hastily took leave of them all and left the room.
column3: He then hastily took leave of them all and left the room.

column2: They saw him step into his carriage, and in a minute it was out of sight.
column3: They saw him step into his carriage, and in a minute it was out of sight.

column2: Mrs. Dashwood felt too much for speech, and instantly quitted the parlour to give way in solitude to the concern and alarm which this sudden departure occasioned.
column3: mrs Dashwood felt too much for speech, and instantly quitted the parlour to give way in solitude to the concern and alarm which this sudden departure occasioned.

column2: Elinor's uneasiness was at least equal to her mother's.
column3: Elinor's uneasiness was at least equal to her mother's.

column2: She thought of what had just passed with anxiety and distrust.
column3: She thought of what had just passed with anxiety and distrust.

column2: Willoughby's behaviour in taking leave of them, his embarrassment, and affectation of cheerfulness, and, above all, his unwillingness to accept her mother's invitation, a backwardness so unlike a lover, so unlike himself, greatly disturbed her.
column3: Willoughby's behaviour in taking leave of them, his embarrassment, and affectation of cheerfulness, and, above all, his unwillingness to accept her mother's invitation, a backwardness so unlike a lover, so unlike himself, greatly disturbed her.

column2: One moment she feared that no serious design had ever been formed on his side; and the next that some unfortunate quarrel had taken place between him and her sister;--the distress in which Marianne had quitted the room was such as a serious quarrel could most reasonably account for, though when she considered what Marianne's love for him was, a quarrel seemed almost impossible.
column3: One moment she feared that no serious design had ever been formed on his side; and the next that some unfortunate quarrel had taken place between him and her sister;--the distress in which Marianne had quitted the room was such as a serious quarrel could most reasonably account for, though when she considered what Marianne's love for him was, a quarrel seemed almost impossible.

column2: But whatever might be the particulars of their separation, her sister's affliction was indubitable; and she thought with the tenderest compassion of that violent sorrow which Marianne was in all probability not merely giving way to as a relief, but feeding and encouraging as a duty.
column3: But whatever might be the particulars of their separation, her sister's affliction was indubitable; and she thought with the tenderest compassion of that violent sorrow which Marianne was in all probability not merely giving way to as a relief, but feeding and encouraging as a duty.

column2: In about half an hour her mother returned, and though her eyes were red, her countenance was not uncheerful.
column3: In about half an hour her mother returned, and though her eyes were red, her countenance was not uncheerful.

column2: Our dear Willoughby is now some miles from Barton, Elinor, said she, as she sat down to work, "and with how heavy a heart does he travel?"
column3: Our dear Willoughby is now some miles from Barton, Elinor, said she, as she sat down to work, "and with how heavy a heart does he travel?"

column2: It is all very strange.	It is all very strange.

column2: So suddenly to be gone!
column3: So suddenly to be gone!

column2: It seems but the work of a moment.
column3: It seems but the work of a moment.

column2: And last night he was with us so happy, so cheerful, so affectionate?
column3: And last night he was with us so happy, so cheerful, so affectionate?

column2: And now, after only ten minutes notice--Gone too without intending to return!--Something more than what he owned to us must have happened.
column3: And now, after only ten minutes notice-Gone too without intending to return!--Something more than what he owned to us must have happened.

column2: He did not speak, he did not behave like himself.
column3: He did not speak, he did not behave like himself.

column2: YOU must have seen the difference as well as I. What can it be?
column3: YOU must have seen the difference as well as i What can it be?

column3: Can they have quarrelled?

column2: Why else should he have shewn such unwillingness to accept your invitation here?"--
column3: Why else should he have shewn such unwillingness to accept your invitation here?"--

column2: It was not inclination that he wanted, Elinor; I could plainly see THAT.	It was not inclination that he wanted, Elinor; I could plainly see THAT.

column2: He had not the power of accepting it.
column3: He had not the power of accepting it.

column2: I have thought it all over I assure you, and I can perfectly account for every thing that at first seemed strange to me as well as to you."
column3: I have thought it all over I assure you, and I can perfectly account for every thing that at first seemed strange to me as well as to you."

column3: Can you, indeed!

column2: I have explained it to myself in the most satisfactory way;--but you, Elinor, who love to doubt where you can--it will not satisfy YOU, I know; but you shall not talk ME out of my trust in it.
column3: I have explained it to myself in the most satisfactory way;--but you, Elinor, who love to doubt where you can-it will not satisfy YOU, I know; but you shall not talk m e out of my trust in it.

column2: I am persuaded that Mrs. Smith suspects his regard for Marianne, disapproves of it, (perhaps because she has other views for him,) and on that account is eager to get him away;--and that the business which she sends him off to transact is invented as an excuse to dismiss him. This is what I believe to have happened.
column3: I am persuaded that mrs Smith suspects his regard for Marianne, disapproves of it, (perhaps because she has other views for him,) and on that account is eager to get him away;--and that the business which she sends him off to transact is invented as an excuse to dismiss him. This is what I believe to have happened.

column2: He is, moreover, aware that she DOES disapprove the connection, he dares not therefore at present confess to her his engagement with Marianne, and he feels himself obliged, from his dependent situation, to give into her schemes, and absent himself from Devonshire for a while.
column3: He is, moreover, aware that she DOES disapprove the connection, he dares not therefore at present confess to her his engagement with Marianne, and he feels himself obliged, from his dependent situation, to give into her schemes, and absent himself from Devonshire for a while.

column2: You will tell me, I know, that this may or may NOT have happened; but I will listen to no cavil, unless you can point out any other method of understanding the affair as satisfactory at this.
column3: You will tell me, I know, that this may or may NOT have happened; but I will listen to no cavil, unless you can point out any other method of understanding the affair as satisfactory at this.

column2: And now, Elinor, what have you to say?"
column3: And now, Elinor, what have you to say?"

column3: Nothing, for you have anticipated my answer.

column2: You had rather take evil upon credit than good.
column3: You had rather take evil upon credit than good.

column3: You had rather look out for misery for Marianne, and guilt for poor Willoughby, than an apology for the latter.

column2: You are resolved to think him blameable, because he took leave of us with less affection than his usual behaviour has shewn.
column3: You are resolved to think him blameable, because he took leave of us with less affection than his usual behaviour has shewn.

column2: And is no allowance to be made for inadvertence, or for spirits depressed by recent disappointment?
column3: And is no allowance to be made for inadvertence, or for spirits depressed by recent disappointment?

column2: Are no probabilities to be accepted, merely because they are not certainties?
column3: Are no probabilities to be accepted, merely because they are not certainties?

column3: Is nothing due to the man whom we have all such reason to love, and no reason in the world to think ill of?

column2: To the possibility of motives unanswerable in themselves, though unavoidably secret for a while?
column3: To the possibility of motives unanswerable in themselves, though unavoidably secret for a while?

column3: And, after all, what is it you suspect him of?"

column2: There is great truth, however, in what you have now urged of the allowances which ought to be made for him, and it is my wish to be candid in my judgment of every body.
column3: There is great truth, however, in what you have now urged of the allowances which ought to be made for him, and it is my wish to be candid in my judgment of every body.

column2: Willoughby may undoubtedly have very sufficient reasons for his conduct, and I will hope that he has. But it would have been more like Willoughby to acknowledge them at once.
column3: Willoughby may undoubtedly have very sufficient reasons for his conduct, and I will hope that he has. But it would have been more like Willoughby to acknowledge them at once.

column2: Secrecy may be advisable; but still I cannot help wondering at its being practiced by him."
column3: Secrecy may be advisable; but still I cannot help wondering at its being practiced by him."

column3: But this is no excuse for their concealing it from us."

column2: This is strange indeed, when your eyes have been reproaching them every day for incautiousness."
column3: This is strange indeed, when your eyes have been reproaching them every day for incautiousness."

column3: I want no proof of their affection, said Elinor; "but of their engagement I do."

column2: I am perfectly satisfied of both.
column3: I am perfectly satisfied of both.

column3: Yet not a syllable has been said to you on the subject, by either of them.

column2: Has not his behaviour to Marianne and to all of us, for at least the last fortnight, declared that he loved and considered her as his future wife, and that he felt for us the attachment of the nearest relation? Have we not perfectly understood each other?
column3: Has not his behaviour to Marianne and to all of us, for at least the last fortnight, declared that he loved and considered her as his future wife, and that he felt for us the attachment of the nearest relation? Have we not perfectly understood each other?

column3: Has not my consent been daily asked by his looks, his manner, his attentive and affectionate respect?

column2: My Elinor, is it possible to doubt their engagement?
column3: My Elinor, is it possible to doubt their engagement?

column3: How could such a thought occur to you?

column2: How is it to be supposed that Willoughby, persuaded as he must be of your sister's love, should leave her, and leave her perhaps for months, without telling her of his affection;--that they should part without a mutual exchange of confidence?"
column3: How is it to be supposed that Willoughby, persuaded as he must be of your sister's love, should leave her, and leave her perhaps for months, without telling her of his affection;--that they should part without a mutual exchange of confidence?"

column2: I confess, replied Elinor, "that every circumstance except ONE is in favour of their engagement; but that ONE is the total silence of both on the subject, and with me it almost outweighs every other."
column3: I confess, replied Elinor, "that every circumstance except ONE is in favour of their engagement; but that ONE is the total silence of both on the subject, and with me it almost outweighs every other."

column3: You must think wretchedly indeed of Willoughby, if, after all that has openly passed between them, you can doubt the nature of the terms on which they are together.

column2: Has he been acting a part in his behaviour to your sister all this time?
column3: Has he been acting a part in his behaviour to your sister all this time?

column3: Do you suppose him really indifferent to her?"

column3: If we find they correspond, every fear of mine will be removed."

column3: Ungracious girl!

column3: You cannot doubt your sister's wishes.

column2: It has been involuntary, and I will not encourage it.

column3: I was startled, I confess, by the alteration in his manners this morning;--he did not speak like himself, and did not return your kindness with any cordiality.

column2: But all this may be explained by such a situation of his affairs as you have supposed.
column3: But all this may be explained by such a situation of his affairs as you have supposed.

column2: He had just parted from my sister, had seen her leave him in the greatest affliction; and if he felt obliged, from a fear of offending Mrs. Smith, to resist the temptation of returning here soon, and yet aware that by declining your invitation, by saying that he was going away for some time, he should seem to act an ungenerous, a suspicious part by our family, he might well be embarrassed and disturbed.
column3: He had just parted from my sister, had seen her leave him in the greatest affliction; and if he felt obliged, from a fear of offending mrs Smith, to resist the temptation of returning here soon, and yet aware that by declining your invitation, by saying that he was going away for some time, he should seem to act an ungenerous, a suspicious part by our family, he might well be embarrassed and disturbed.

column2: In such a case, a plain and open avowal of his difficulties would have been more to his honour I think, as well as more consistent with his general character;--but I will not raise objections against any one's conduct on so illiberal a foundation, as a difference in judgment from myself, or a deviation from what I may think right and consistent."

column2: Though WE have not known him long, he is no stranger in this part of the world; and who has ever spoken to his disadvantage? column3: They were interrupted by the entrance of Margaret; and Elinor was then at liberty to think over the representations of her mother, to acknowledge the probability of many, and hope for the justice of all.

column2: They saw nothing of Marianne till dinner time, when she entered the room and took her place at the table without saying a word.

column3: Her eyes were red and swollen; and it seemed as if her tears were even then restrained with difficulty.

column3: She avoided the looks of them all, could neither eat nor speak, and after some time, on her mother's silently pressing her hand with tender compassion, her small degree of fortitude was quite overcome, she burst into tears and left the room.

column3: This violent oppression of spirits continued the whole evening.

column2: She was without any power, because she was without any desire of command over herself.
column3: She was without any power, because she was without any desire of command over herself.

column2: The slightest mention of anything relative to Willoughby overpowered her in an instant; and though her family were most anxiously attentive to her comfort, it was impossible for them, if they spoke at all, to keep clear of every subject which her feelings connected with him.
column3: The slightest mention of anything relative to Willoughby overpowered her in an instant; and though her family were most anxiously attentive to her comfort, it was impossible for them, if they spoke at all, to keep clear of every subject which her feelings connected with him.

column3: She would have been ashamed to look her family in the face the next morning, had she not risen from her bed in more need of repose than when she lay down in it.

column2: But the feelings which made such composure a disgrace, left her in no danger of incurring it.

column3: She was awake the whole night, and she wept the greatest part of it.

column3: She got up with a headache, was unable to talk, and unwilling to take any nourishment; giving pain every moment to her mother and sisters, and forbidding all attempt at consolation from either.

column2: Her sensibility was potent enough!
